title: Tube strike dealt a heavy blow to London's retailers
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Fri, Sep 4, 2015, 17:08 BST - UK Markets closed Tube strike dealt a heavy blow to London's retailers By Ashley Armstrong | Telegraph – 1 hour 12 minutes ago 19.25 -0.73 
Last month's tube strike led to a 9.5pc drop in the number of shoppers in the capital 
The tube strike last month heaped misery on retailers in London, who are already struggling to cope with declining shopper numbers. 
The number of shoppers in London and the suburbs tumbled by 9.5pc in the first week of August when the City was brought to a standstill by a 24-hour tube strike. 
Many people attempted to work from home or avoided the capital to escape the travel chaos. 
The figures by Ipsos Retail Performance, which measures the number of shoppers visiting over 4,000 non-retail food stores across the UK, also reported that footfall fell by 5.4pc in August, compared to the month before. 
“A dip during August is always expected, with many people away on summer holiday, but not to the extent that we saw this month”, Tim Denison, director of retail intelligence at Ipsos (Paris: FR 73298 - news ) said. “In fact, with a month-on-month decline of -6.7pc, it was the greatest July to August swing since 2003.” 
The dismal performance follows figures from BDO which revealed that August was the worst month for British high street retailers since the financial crisis in November 2008. 
British retailers are losing out, despite a rise in spending power, as consumers are increasingly choosing to spend their money on travelling abroad and meals out, rather than in the shops. 
The summer's unpredictable, wet and stormy weather didn't help either, as it dampened enthusiasm to head out on the high street. 
However, Mr Denison said he didn't believe the disappointing figures were a cause for concern or that they represented an underlying trend in the sector. 
"The causes seem to be more isolated events, culminating to impact on shoppers’ physical trips to the store," he said. "We view August’s footfall decline simply as a blip, and something that should not be repeated in September. Regular pay growth continues to improve and the housing market is regaining its vigour.”
